verses.text: Hannah prayed and said: 'My heart rejoices in the LORD; my horn is lifted high in the LORD. My mouth speaks boldly against my enemies, for I rejoice in Your salvation.'
verses.comment: Hannah's song is a poetic prayer celebrating God's victory and salvation, similar to Mary's Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55). 'Horn' represents strength and dignity (cf. Ps. 132:17).

verses.text: There is no one holy like the LORD; there is no one besides You; there is no rock like our God.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the absolute uniqueness and holiness of God, using the imagery of a 'rock' as a symbol of stability and faithfulness. Compare with Moses’ song in Deut. 32.

verses.text: Do not keep speaking so proudly—let no arrogance come from your mouth. For the LORD is a God of knowledge, and by Him actions are weighed.
verses.comment: God is the ultimate judge of motives and actions, showing His omniscience and justice. Spiritual pride is contrasted with humility.

verses.text: The bows of the mighty are broken, but those who stumbled are armed with strength.
verses.comment: Themes of reversal and divine justice, God humbles the strong, lifts the lowly. Compare to Mary’s song and Beatitudes in Luke 1.

verses.text: Those who were full have hired themselves out for bread, but those who were hungry have stopped being in need. Even the barren has borne seven, but she who has many children has grown weak.
verses.comment: God reverses earthly fortunes, giving children to the barren—a fulfillment seen in Hannah herself, echoing deeper spiritual meanings of God's grace.

verses.text: The LORD brings death and gives life; He brings down to Sheol and raises up.
verses.comment: This verse anticipates New Testament resurrection hope, with God as giver of life and resurrection. Compare to Christ's authority in giving life (John 5:21).

verses.text: The LORD makes poor and makes rich; He brings down and He lifts up.
verses.comment: God's sovereign power over material and social status, paralleling the Lord's Beatitudes (Matt. 5) and the themes of humility and exultation.

verses.text: He raises the poor from the dust and lifts the needy from the ash heap to make them sit with princes and inherit a seat of honor. For the pillars of the earth are the LORD’s, and He has set the world upon them.
verses.comment: Themes of reversal—God elevates the humble. The 'pillars of the earth' symbolism connects to God’s sovereignty in creation and establishes His universal kingship.

verses.text: He guards the steps of His faithful ones, but the wicked are silenced in darkness. For it is not by strength that one prevails;
verses.comment: 'Faithful ones' may reference those set apart for God, reflecting on God’s providential care and connecting with the ongoing idea of a remnant chosen by grace.

verses.text: Those who oppose the LORD will be shattered. He thunders against them in the heavens; the LORD will judge the ends of the earth. He will give strength to His king and exalt the horn of His anointed.”
verses.comment: 'Anointed' (Hebrew: Messiah) foreshadows not only Israel’s kings but also Christ Himself. The first biblical mention of God's 'king' in history—an early sign pointing toward Jesus, who fulfills the role of anointed King, and the Last Judgment.

verses.text: Then Elkanah went home to Ramah, but the boy served the LORD in the presence of Eli the priest.
verses.comment: Samuel’s dedication mirrors later dedications in Christian practice, with parallels to the boy Jesus serving in the Temple (Luke 2:49).

verses.text: Now the sons of Eli were worthless men; they did not know the LORD.
verses.comment: The Hebrew literally reads 'sons of Belial,' which means 'worthless.' Their ignorance of God despite their position shows the importance of true spiritual knowledge.

verses.text: Now it was the custom of the priests with the people that whenever any man offered a sacrifice, the priest’s servant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand, while the meat was boiling,
verses.comment: Highlights misuse by the priests’ family. The eating ritual is rooted in Levitical law, but Eli’s sons corrupted it for personal gain.

verses.text: and would thrust it into the pan or kettle or caldron or pot; the priest would take for himself all that the fork brought up. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came to Shiloh.
verses.comment: Contrast between proper worship rituals and their abuse by the sons of Eli. True priestly ministry must serve God, not self.

verses.text: Even before the fat was burned, the servant of the priest would come and say to the man who was sacrificing, 'Give meat to roast for the priest; he will not accept boiled meat from you, but only raw.'
verses.comment: Taking meat before the fat was burned directly violated sacrificial law. Spiritual leaders are warned against abusing their sacred duties.

verses.text: If the man said to him, 'Let the fat be burned first, and then take what you want,' he would answer, 'No, you must give it now; and if not, I will take it by force.'
verses.comment: The priests' servants demand what belongs to God, showing how religious corruption harms true worship—fulfilling warnings given to unfaithful shepherds (cf. Ezekiel 34).

verses.text: Thus the sin of the young men was very great in the sight of the LORD, for they treated the LORD’s offering with contempt.
verses.comment: Disrespect towards the offering prefigures warnings against treating God’s sacraments and worship lightly (cf. Heb. 10:29).

verses.text: But Samuel was serving before the LORD—a boy clothed with a linen ephod.
verses.comment: The linen ephod marks Samuel as set apart for special service, foreshadowing the office of a true, faithful priesthood.

verses.text: His mother would make him a little robe and bring it to him year by year, when she went up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.
verses.comment: Hannah’s faithfulness in bringing the robe mirrors the ongoing relationship between family, worship, and dedication to God.

verses.text: Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, saying, 'May the LORD give you children from this woman for the gift she gave to the LORD.' Then they would return to their home.
verses.comment: Eli’s blessing foretells more children for Hannah—a picture of God’s ongoing kindness and multiplication of grace when offering is made with a right heart.

verses.text: And the LORD visited Hannah, and she conceived and bore three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew up in the presence of the LORD.
verses.comment: God's faithful blessing to Hannah parallels spiritual fruitfulness. Samuel 'growing in the presence of the Lord' echoes Christ’s own growth (Luke 2:52).

verses.text: Now Eli was very old, and he kept hearing all that his sons were doing to all Israel, and how they lay with the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: This immorality at the sanctuary marks a dramatic corruption of priestly office. The women were possibly religious servants—reminding us of the importance of holiness in ministry.

verses.text: So he said to them, 'Why do you do such things? For I hear of your evil dealings from all these people.'
verses.comment: Eli, as priest, reproves his sons—though somewhat mildly. God’s justice later responds strongly where human discipline is weak.

verses.text: 'No, my sons; it is not a good report that I hear the people of the LORD spreading abroad.'
verses.comment: Their actions damage the community’s witness. Leadership failures in worship matter profoundly, affecting God’s people.

verses.text: If one man sins against another, God will mediate for him; but if someone sins against the LORD, who can intercede for him?' But they would not listen to the voice of their father, for the LORD desired to put them to death.
verses.comment: The gravity of direct sin against God is highlighted here. A hint toward the later office of true intercession—fulfilled perfectly in Christ as the one mediator (1 Tim. 2:5), connecting priestly mediation.

verses.text: But the boy Samuel continued to grow both in stature and in favor with the LORD and with people.
verses.comment: Samuel’s spiritual and natural growth closely parallels the description of Jesus, further foreshadowing the development of God’s true servants.

verses.text: And a man of God came to Eli and said to him, 'Thus says the LORD: "Did I not plainly reveal Myself to your father’s house when they were in Egypt under Pharaoh’s house?
verses.comment: The unnamed prophet invokes God’s historical call of Aaron, establishing a divine line of priestly authority and warning against betraying that trust.

verses.text: 'Did I not choose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to go up to My altar, to burn incense, to wear an ephod before Me? And I gave to the house of your father all the offerings made by fire from the people of Israel.'
verses.comment: The privileges granted to priestly office were matched by responsibility; their failure is greater because of their high calling.

verses.text: 'Why do you kick at My sacrifice and My offering that I have commanded in My dwelling place, and honor your sons above Me by fattening yourselves on the choicest parts of every offering of My people Israel?'
verses.comment: Idolatry and self-indulgence among leaders are severely rebuked here. God’s honor must come first—even above family ties—hinting at Jesus’ words on family and discipleship.

verses.text: Therefore the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'I promised that your house and the house of your father should go in and out before Me forever,' but now the LORD declares: 'Far be it from Me! For those who honor Me I will honor, but those who despise Me shall be lightly esteemed.'
verses.comment: Though God’s promises are lasting, continued faithfulness is required. True succession involves faith as well as lineage—suggesting the importance of visible, continuous leadership.

verses.text: 'Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father’s house, so that there will not be an old man in your house.'
verses.comment: Prophetic judgment against Eli’s line is fulfilled in chapter 4. The faithlessness of the priestly house results in removal from ministry, showing the seriousness of spiritual responsibility.

verses.text: 'Then you will look with envy upon the prosperity that will come to Israel, but there shall not be an old man in your house forever.'
verses.comment: Contrast between God’s blessing on Israel and judgment on those unfaithful to His service. Leadership that fails in holiness loses its privileges.

verses.text: 'Any one of you whom I do not cut off from My altar shall be spared only to weep his eyes out and grieve his heart, and all the descendants of your house shall die by the sword of men.'
verses.comment: God’s justice will leave an enduring sign of judgment—a sober warning against presumption and the misuse of spiritual authority.

verses.text: 'And this that shall come upon your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, shall be a sign to you: both of them shall die on the same day.'
verses.comment: The specific prophecy finds literal fulfillment shortly thereafter. God’s warnings are always just—and are given for repentance.

verses.text: 'And I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest, who shall do according to what is in My heart and in My mind. I will build him a sure house, and he shall walk before My anointed forever.'
verses.comment: This is a messianic prophecy ultimately pointing to Christ, the high priest who lives forever (Hebrews 7:16-17), but also prefigures a continuing visible line of priestly leadership.

verses.text: 'And everyone who is left in your house shall come to implore him for a piece of silver or a loaf of bread and shall say, Please appoint me to some priestly duty, that I may eat a morsel of bread.'"
verses.comment: Those who abused their calling are reduced to begging from the faithful priest. A powerful warning and a pattern urging faithfulness and humility for leadership in God’s household.
